etymology.description: semantic: 爿(爿) (pán, 'bed') + phonetic: 丬(丬) (jiāng, phonetic component) = leading by taking to bed (figurative for keeping close control) -> lead
etymology.interpretation: The character 将(將) combines 爿(爿) (pán, 'bed') as a semantic indicator suggesting the idea of handling or supporting, with 丬(丬) for its phonetic contribution, creating a representation of leading or taking charge.
etymology.simplification: 將(將)→将(將): 爿(爿) (pán, 'bed') was removed entirely, retaining only the simplified phonetic 丬(丬).

examples.chinese: 他将军队带向胜利(他將軍隊帶向勝利)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jiāng jūnduì dài xiàng shènglì.
examples.english: He leads the army towards victory.

examples.chinese: 将领率队征战沙场(將領率隊征戰沙場)，赢得民心拥戴(贏得民心擁戴)。
examples.pinyin: Jiānglǐng shuài duì zhēngzhàn shāchǎng, yíngdé mínxīn yōngdài.
examples.english: The general leads his troops into battle, winning the people's admiration.
